thread.title: Memmott: Hey, Rochester, try these slogans on for size
thread.title_full: Memmott: Hey, Rochester, try these slogans on for size

author: Jim Memmott
title: Memmott: Hey, Rochester, try these slogans on for size
text:
Inspired by my discovery of a sticker proclaiming, "I'd rather be in Rochester," one of our area's many abandoned slogans, I asked readers last week to nominate a new motto for Rochester. I was hoping for something that honored the past, celebrated the present and forecast the future. I know that's asking a lot.
A couple dozen people emailed me; a small but pleasing group made use of the United States Postal Service. Over 100 people weighed in on Facebook.
Some of their comments focused on Rochester's problems. There are real problems, for sure, but mottoes tend to shine a light on the positive, so I'll stick with the upbeat.
Perhaps not surprisingly, several nominees focused — tongue in cheek, I'm sure — on our city's signature dish.
Rochester: Where We Eat our Garbage on a Plate (Rob Keim), and Rochester: A Cultural Garbage Plate (Michelle Spring), would play well here but might confuse outsiders.
Poll: Which slogan is your favorite?
And Suzanne Lanyak had offered a hot dog allusion that would ring a Zweigle's bell locally: Rochester: It's hot…white hot!
Surprise, our area's sometimes challenging weather made for these mottoes:
Rochester: Where you can get frostbite and sunburn in the same week (Maureen Ó Brien Placilla; Rochester: Where every day is different (Joyce Maddalena); Rochester: We weather it better (Rebecca Porter); and Rochester: A city for all seasons, even in one day (Nance Camilleri).
I've noted before that Rochesterians don't like to brag, and this tendency was reflected in these modest mottoes that I liked, even though civic slogans aren't supposed to be self-effacing:
Rochester: No, not the one in Minnesota (Anna Kenny); Rochester: It's an acquired taste (Charles Dinsmore); and Rochester: At least it's cheap (Suzanne Lanyak).
And I'm not sure if it's modesty or low-bar setting, but a few of the suggestions raised Rochester up by taking other cities down, as in Rochester: At Least it ain't Syracuse (Jay Ferris) or Rochester: At Least it's not Cleveland (John Hamlett).
Rochester is a literary town, what with all the colleges, so it was to be expected that at least one entry was in the form of a haiku: Rochester: Surprising Rest'raunts/World-class art and museums/all within your reach (Steve Terry).
And now, let's try to pick a winner. The poll here includes one — Rochester: Limitless — that is going to be the motto created by Jay Advertising for a new campaign by Visit Rochester.
In each case the motto is followed by its creator/supporter in parentheses.
We'll announce the winner or winners in a couple weeks.
1. Rochester Rocks or Rochester Rocs (nominated by several people.)
2. Rochester: Gem on the Genesee (Michele Spring, Pete Schickler)
3. Rochester: Historically Progressive (Alinda Drury, Kate Morse)
4. Rochester: Limitless (Visit Rochester)
5. Rochester: Light the way to the future (Judy Pfau Hull)
6. Rochester: City of Vision (Keith Perez).
DEMOCRATANDCHRONICLE.COM
Remarkable Rochesterians
On Remarkable Rochester
Retired Senior Editor Jim Memmott reflects on what makes Rochester distinctively Rochester, its history, its habits, its people. Contact him at: (585) 278-8012 or jmemmott@DemocratandChronicle.com or Remarkable Rochester, Box 274, Geneseo, NY 14454.
Remarkable Rochesterians
Featured in the July issue of Rochester Magazine , the visionary deserves a spot on the list of Remarkable Rochesterians found at RocRoots.com :
Myron Holley (Photo: Provided)
Myron Holley (1752-1841): He supervised the construction of the western half of the Erie Canal, making sure it flowed through downtown Rochester, thus opening the city's products to the west. A native of Connecticut, he gave up his law practice in Canandaigua rather than defend a man whom he believed was guilty of murder. He also was a bookseller and served as the Ontario County clerk and a member of the state Assembly. He later was a leader in the anti-slavery movement and a founder of the Liberty Party. The village of Holley carries his name.
